title: Bullies 'taped boy's eyes shut and scratched shapes into his stomach' in Wales | Metro News
text:
Jen Mills for Metro.co.uk Wednesday 15 Feb 2017 3:10 pm They pinned him down and scratched shapes into his stomach (Picture: SouthWales-EveningPost.co.uk) 
Parents have withdrawn their son from a primary school after bullies pinned him down, taped his eyes shut and carved shapes into his stomach. 
The unnamed boy, now aged 11, was so frightened during the ordeal that he wet himself, his parents said. Family release shocking photos of bullied teen attacked on his way home from school 
It left him so terrified of going back to school that he hid his shoes to try to get out of going to class, and regularly wets the bed, they said. 
His family have released a shocking image of the boy’s stomach, showing the injuries he was left with after classmates carved shapes into him using a bamboo stick. 
Keeping him anonymous to protect his identity, his parents said bullies had told him he would ‘have no friends’ if he told anyone what happened. Stebonhealth Primary School in Llanelli (Picture: Google maps) 
It happened in April last year, and the bullies were suspended from school for a month. Pizza delivery driver leaves note offering 'weed, MDMA, pills, ket, raw coke & much more' 
But last week, his parents said he had been targeted again. 
Other bullies are said to have told their son: ‘We wish you had cancer and would die’– which they said the school merely wrote off as ‘boys will be boys.’ 
Last Wednesday he came home from school with two lumps on the back of the head after his head was forced against the floor, they said. 
His parents said they’ve finally had enough and are removing their son and his older sibling from Stebonheath Primary School in Llanelli, West Wales, for good. 
‘Our son has had a heartbreaking time, but now he’s left he is over the moon, and very relieved,’ they said. ‘We just wanted to tell others what has happened to us. We don’t want it to happen to anyone else.’ The school responded 
Stebonheath Primary School said they had followed proper procedures when the carving incident was reported, and are now investigating the latest attack on the boy. 
A spokeswoman said: ‘The school has followed all policy and procedures appropriately in respect of the historic incident and the current allegations are under investigation. 
‘We can confirm that parents have withdrawn two siblings from the school.’ More
